data: Let 𝐴 be an 𝑚×𝑛 matrix, and let 𝑏 be a vector in ℝ𝑚. A least-squares solution to the matrix equation 𝐴𝑥=𝑏 is denoted as 𝑥̂ in ℝ𝑛, and it satisfies the condition that dist(𝑏, 𝐴𝑥̂)≤dist(𝑏, 𝐴𝑥) for any other vectors 𝑥 in ℝ𝑛. The column space, Col(𝐴), represents all vectors manifested as 𝐴𝑥. Recall that the distance between two vectors 𝑣 and 𝑤 can be defined as dist(𝑣, 𝑤)=‖𝑣−𝑤‖. The term “least squares” signifies that dist(𝑏, 𝐴𝑥)=‖𝑏−𝐴𝑥̂‖ expresses the square root of the sum of the squares of the components of the vector 𝑏−𝐴𝑥̂. Essentially, finding a least-squares solution entails minimizing the sum of squared differences between the elements of 𝐴𝑥̂ and 𝑏. Accordingly, this approach seeks to invalidate the equation 𝐴𝑥=𝑏 as accurately as possible by cutting down the squared discrepancies 𝑏−𝐴𝑥. Therefore, the optimal vector of the form 𝐴𝑥 that approximates 𝑏 is represented as the orthogonal projection of 𝑏 on Col(𝐴), indicated as 𝑏Col(𝐴).
goal:
**Create a visualization to explain the concept of the least-squares solution as the orthogonal projection of a vector onto the column space of a matrix.** The goal of this visualization is to illustrate how the vector \( b \) in \( \mathbb{R}^m \) can be approximated by a vector \( A\hat{x} \) within the column space \( \text{Col}(A) \) through the minimization of the distance \( \|b - A\hat{x}\| \). By emphasizing the relationship between the vectors and their distances, the visual will clarify the significance of the orthogonal projection in achieving the least-squares solution.

The visualization should adopt a diagrammatic style, showcasing the geometrical interpretation of vectors, projections, and distance. It should visually represent \( b \), the column space \( \text{Col}(A) \), and the orthogonal projection \( b_{\text{Col}(A)} \), with arrows indicating the distances involved. This will deepen understanding by highlighting cause-and-effect relationships between the approximation error and its minimization, reinforcing the concept that the least-squares solution is the best approximation in terms of minimizing squared distances.

**Learning Objective:** Students will develop a comprehensive understanding of how the least-squares solution functions as an orthogonal projection of the vector \( b \) onto the column space of matrix \( A \), allowing them to visualize and interpret the underlying mathematical relationships that govern this principle.
code:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Define the vectors
b = np.array([3, 4])
A_col1 = np.array([1, 0])
A_col2 = np.array([0, 2])
A = np.column_stack((A_col1, A_col2))

# Calculate the orthogonal projection of b onto the column space of A
A_pseudo_inv = np.linalg.pinv(A)
x_hat = A_pseudo_inv @ b
b_col_A = A @ x_hat

# Create the plot
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))
plt.quiver(0, 0, b[0], b[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='r', label='Vector b')
plt.quiver(0, 0, b_col_A[0], b_col_A[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='g', label='Projection $b_{Col(A)}$')
plt.quiver(b_col_A[0], b_col_A[1], b[0] - b_col_A[0], b[1] - b_col_A[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='b', linestyle='dashed', label='Error $b - b_{Col(A)}$')

# Set limits and grid
plt.xlim(-1, 5)
plt.ylim(-1, 5)
plt.axhline(0, color='black',linewidth=0.5, ls='dotted')
plt.axvline(0, color='black',linewidth=0.5, ls='dotted')
plt.grid(color = 'gray', linestyle = '--', linewidth = 0.5)

# Draw the column space lines
plt.plot([0, A_col1[0]], [0, A_col1[1]], 'k', linewidth=2, alpha=0.7)
plt.plot([0, A_col2[0]], [0, A_col2[1]], 'k', linewidth=2, alpha=0.7)

# Labels and title
plt.text(b[0]/2, b[1]/2, 'b', fontsize=12, verticalalignment='bottom', horizontalalignment='right', color='r')
plt.text(b_col_A[0]/2, b_col_A[1]/2, '$b_{Col(A)}$', fontsize=12, verticalalignment='bottom', horizontalalignment='right', color='g')
plt.text((b[0] + b_col_A[0]) / 2, (b[1] + b_col_A[1]) / 2, '$\\|b - b_{Col(A)}\\|$', fontsize=12, verticalalignment='bottom', horizontalalignment='right', color='b')

plt.title('Least-Squares Solution as Orthogonal Projection')
plt.xlabel('x-axis')
plt.ylabel('y-axis')
plt.legend()
plt.axis('equal')
